title: (x) "Propane" Garamond-like face - Monotype Garamond, Palatino {Lex, Yves}
content:
Italian Garamond and Monotype Garamond are very close but the P does’nt match up... ?? Mixed bag?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164159im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/bob_4504.jpg)

 [‹ What is this script font?](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164159/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43177 "Go to previous forum topic") [Please ID (or suggest) ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164159/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43127 "Go to next forum topic")
author: amiart

comments.content:
Where does this sample come from?

As you say, Monotype Garamond is almost an exact match, so I think it’s at least based on that.

- Lex
Hahaha, yes. But Lex and the others wanted to know, where you found it: In which newspaper, magazine, logo, …? Sometimes the people here can identify it by knowing the source of the sample.

Exactly. There’s a big difference between a scan from a magazine ad from 1967 and a graphic you found on a website.

- Lex
The P is Palatino. How quaint. :^/

The Stempel Garamond has this upper case P

Georg  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
„Ich bin ein Preuße, kennt Ihr meine Farben...“

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164159im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/1_5663.jpg)

It’s not the same as the example though - notice the squared-off serifs and differently shaped bowl.

Nick Cooke
The P is Palatino. Trust me. :^)
